COVID-19 IOM Zimbabwe 2017 - 2021. MR - Övervakning, skydd och främjande

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The goal of the support is to strengthen the monitoring and protection of human rights in Zimbabwe by providing support to a number of key organizations engaged in human rights monitoring, awareness raising for the public regarding their human rights, legal support and litigation assistance to people affected by human rights violations, as well as organizations dealing with the care of persons exposed to politically motivated violence and torture

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det övergripande målet med insatsen är att bidra till stärkta mänskliga rättigheter för utsatta grupper och personer i Zimbabwe. Stödet syftar till att stärka övervakning och skydd av mänskliga rättigheter i Zimbabwe, genom att ge stöd till ett antal nyckelorganisationer som arbetar med MR-övervakning, utbildning för allmänheten om deras mänskliga rättigheter, rättsligt stöd och hjälp för de som utsätts för MR-övergrepp, samt organisationer som arbetar med vård av personer som utsatts för politiskt motiverat våld och tortyr. Förväntade resultat (outcomes) är: 1. Ökad tillgång till information för medborgare/rättighetsbärare (flickor och pojkar, kvinnor och män i Zimbabwe) om sina mänskliga rättigheter och stärkt kapacitet för att skydda dessa, från grästrotsnivå upp till nationell nivå. 2. Stärkt kapacitet för effektivt samarbete mellan medborgargrupper/civila samhället och de som är skyldiga att respektera, främja, skydda och uppfylla dessa rättigheter (ansvarstagare). 3. Stärkt övervakning av respekt för mänskliga rättigheter. 4. Stärkta system för hantering av övergrepp mot mänskliga rättigheter.
Projektet genomförs av International Organization of Migration (IOM) i Harare tillsammans med ett nätverk av civilsamhällesorganisationer. Projektet bygger vidare på ett pågående stöd till IOM från EU. EU kommer med stor sannolikhet att bidra med ytterligare medel till projektet från och med mars 2018.
Ambassaden bedömer att den föreslagna insatsen uppfyller ett flertal resultat under strategin för Sveriges utvecklingssamarbete med Zimbabwe 2017-2021. Insatsen relaterar också till följande mål för FNs globala mål för hållbarutveckling; Mål 3 Hälsa och Välbefinnande, Mål 5 Jämställdhet, och, framförallt, Mål 16 Fredliga och Inkluderande samhällen.

description.narrative:
The IOM intervention recorded achievements on Human Rights Protection and COVID 19 response as follows: Key Highlight on Human Rights Protection Achievements: - The project reached out to 105,090 individuals in 2020 with direct emergency lifesaving assistance across the 10 provinces of Zimbabwe. Provision of support to 80,700 vulnerable individuals with advocacy/ appeal to local and national authorities, through advocacy, medical attention/hospitalisation, legal representation, counselling, non-food items, shelter, and mobile legal outreach services. - A total of 1,514 clients received medical and mental health and psychosocial support from Counselling Services Unit (CSU). These were mainly victims of state security brutality targeting civilians and vendors for allegedly violating the lockdown regulations. These victims reported being severely assaulted, detained in overcrowded police cells, forced to pay bribes for their release or some losing their wares they would be selling. - In 2020 the project managed profile 2,280 human rights violations affecting 207, 195 individuals marking 17,9 per cent increase as compared to 2019. Medical care, mental health and psychosocial support, emergency shelter and advocacy support, was provided to 113,672 beneficiaries. Legal support was provided for 54 cases responding to forced displacements evictions, freedom for human rights defenders and other public litigations. This is highlighted below:
- ZHRC conducted assessment on the general human rights situation in the country. Provision of capacity building and support to CSO partners and community with to identify, document and report human rights violations. - Zimbabwe Peace Project (ZPP) implemented a module to trained monitors, improving their skills, techniques, and methods of human rights monitoring. - Advocacy platforms were established to strengthen constitutional awareness, policy formulation and resilience building. IOM developed a Protection Information Management System (PIMS) to strengthen data processing, analysis, and mapping of hotspots. Summary of key highlights of the COVD-19 response - Covid Isolation tents were set up at border level to ensure separation of symptomatic patients (Migrants) in eight POEs (Beitbridge, Plumtree, Chirundu, Nyamapanda, Forbes, Sango, Kariba, Kazungula). - Port Health was assisted by 15 IOM nurses engaged in the different Points of Entries (POEs) (Beitbridge, Plumtree, Chirundu, Nyamapanda, Forbes, Sango, Kariba, Kazungula) to collaborate in the screening registration and profiling of returnees, as well as testing and provision of basic medical services. - Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) campaigns were conducting in 11 districts, covering health promotion and information dissemination in POE and border communities. - All the POEs (Beitbridge, Plumtree, Chirundu, Nyamapanda, Forbes, Sango, Kariba, Kazungula) were targeted with capacity building activities, nine trainings were conducted with front line workers and different stakeholders involved in COVID-19 response, health risks and preventive measures, case management, Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) and Mental Health Psychosocial Support (MHPSS). - Standard Operation Procedures (SOPs) were developed in case management at POEs and management of Isolation and Quarantine centers with IPC and Self-Isolation content developed in collaboration with RCCE, IPC and Case management Pillar. - A total of 594, Handwashing stations were established at POEs, border quarantine facilities, border communities and key migrant sending areas, to enhanced hygiene practices and preventive measures. - A special report was produced by ZimRights, documenting the devastating effect of the pandemic on livelihoods.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
